text: this is the livadia palace niota in the
crimea and it was in these dramatic
surroundings back in 1945 that Stalin
Churchill and Roosevelt soon to be the
victors of World War two smets to decide
what the post-war world should look like
and to agree on the rules of the
geopolitical game we did this moment of
the Churchill Roosevelt Stalin meeting
and this is where the deal was signed
the so-called great powers deciding the
big issues of the day now fast-forward
72 years and in Russia today there are
lots of politicians and pundits who call
for a new you to style agreement a new
grand bargain between Russia and the
West between Vladimir Putin and Donald
Trump but what might Russia want out of
such a deal well again based on the
chatter in the Russian political elite
this is what Moscow is looking for the
starters a promise that NATO troops will
move away from Russia's borders and a
guarantee that Ukraine and Georgia won't
join the alliance Moscow also wants the
West to accept that the former Soviet
space is Russia's sphere of influence
and that annex Crimea is part of Russia
and then there are those US and EU
sanctions against Russia Moscow wants
them scrapped and one more thing russia
wants to be recognized again as a
superpower as one of the boys at the top
table calling the shots which is all
very well but right now the chances of
an east-west deal are rapidly receding
even if Donald Trump were to agree to
Moscow's wishes he's under such pressure
right now over his alleged links to
Russia that making major concessions
would spark outrage back home Plus after
the US missile strike on Syria for now
the priority has become not a grand
bargain but avoiding a major
confrontation between east and west
Steve Rosenberg BBC news than livadia
palace crimea
